wikipedia_page.main:
George Talbot (1761 – 1850) was an English cricketer.  He was an early Marylebone Cricket Club (MCC) member who had previously been elected a Hambledon Club member in 1788.  He played in 23 recorded matches from 1785 to 1791 and was a useful batsman.
In HCC, he is mentioned in connection with "some quaint wagers" in the betting book at White's Club.  A member of the military, he eventually succeeded to his family title as 3rd Baronet.

response: | colspan="5" | The Earl of Winchilsea didn’t play because he was unwell. The detailed scorecard has not survived but the WCC team was Sir Peter Burrell, Mr John Peachey, Mr – Dampier, Capt. Charles Cumberland, Mr G East, Mr Assheton Smith, Mr George Talbot, Mr Richard Newman, Mr R B Wyatt, Mr Edward Hussey and Mr C Drummond.

| colspan="5" | In this game, White Conduit combined with Moulsey Hurst Club in order to take on Hornchurch. The exact result is uncertain but it was by over 100 runs: WCC scored 89 and at least 162; Hornchurch 100 and not above 50. The only player mentioned in WDC is Winchilsea who scored between 20 and 30 but whether in one innings or in the whole match we do not know. The stake was 500 guineas. The teams are in FL18 but no scorecard information. The WCC/MHC team was Earl of Winchilsea, Sir Peter Burrell, Mr G East, Mr George Talbot, Mr C Drummond, Mr G Boult, Mr – Slater, Mr George Louch, William Bedster, Edward "Lumpy" Stevens and – Davy (Surrey); Lumpy and Davy were professional bowlers.
*George Talbot, 6th Earl of Shrewsbury (1528–1590), English statesman
*George Talbot, 9th Earl of Shrewsbury (1566–1630), Roman Catholic priest
*George Talbot (judge) (1861–1938), Judge of the High Court of Justice
*George Talbot (entomologist) (1882–1952), English entomologist who specialised in butterflies
*George Talbot (New Zealand cricketer) (1907–1943), New Zealand cricketer
